results.title: Ace Ventura: pet detective
results.creator_credit: Tom Shadyac, James G. Robinson and Morgan Creek
results.brief_description: There’s hope out there for all distraught pet owners concerned about the disappearance of their pets; Ace Ventura, pet detective, whose leading the small but exclusive field. Ace is contacted by the beautiful Melissa (Courteney Cox), to locate Snowflake, dolphin mascot of the Miami Football team and good luck charm. Ace is not only up against a ruthless kidnapper, but scorn and resistance from the police force who have the utmost contempt for his profession. Cast includes Jim Carrey, Sean Young, Courteney Cox, Tone Loc and Dan Marino (Miami Dolphins).

results.title: Ace Ventura: when nature calls
results.creator_credit: Steve Oedekerk, James G. Robinson and Morgan Creek
results.brief_description: Jim Carrey again stars as Ace Ventura, the animal sleuth with the gravity-defying hairstyle in this sequel to ‘Ace Ventura, Pet Detective’ (309280). In the deepest jungles of Africa, two tribes will fight a savage war unless their sacred animal god is found, so they’re sending for the only man who can help, Ace Ventura. Africa will never be the same again as Ace discovers the animal within and answers the call of the wild in this out-there comedy. Cast includes Jim Carrey, Ian McNeice, Simon Callow, Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje and Maynard Eziashi.

results.title: Stealing beauty
results.creator_credit: Bernardo Bertolucci, Jeremy Thomas, Fox Searchlight, UGC Images and Recorded Picture Company
results.brief_description: Nineteen-year-old Lucy (Liv Tyler) goes to stay in the Tuscan countryside with old friends of her late mother. This is a time of discovery for Lucy: inspired by the free-spirit of the bohemian characters who take special interest in her virginity (or loss of), she explores a romance with a local Italian boy. Her mentor is Alex (Jeremy Irons), who is a writer on the brink of death. Bertolucci is pre-occupied with aesthetics in this film and the focus is very much on the beauty of the Tuscan countryside, and of Liv Tyler. Cast includes Sinead Cusack, Jean Marais, Donal McCann, Stefania Sandrelli, Joseph Fiennes.

results.title: Desperado
results.creator_credit: Robert Rodriguez, Bill Borden, Los Hooligans and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Antonio Banderas; armed with a guitar, singing voice, a way with women and an armament of weaponry is El Mariachi; legend across the desolate wastelands of America. He is driven by revenge, drifting through towns in search of drug dealer Bucho, the one responsible for killing his girlfriend. He has a new woman in his life now, Carolina (Salma Hayek), who has her own reasons for helping him. El Mariachi wages a one man war against Bucho’s henchmen, with the onslaught of violence set against a vibrant backdrop of Latin American music. Cast includes Joaquim de Almeida, Steve Buscemi, Cheech Marin and Quentin Tarantino.

results.title: The Parent trap
results.brief_description: A summer camp turns into a life altering adventure when two long lost twin sisters (both played by Hayley Mills), are reunited. Together the newly formed friends devise a fiendish plot to rekindle the romance between their separated parents and live as one happy family. With two minds on the job there’s double the chance of success! Cast includes Maureen O’Hara, Brian Keith, Charlie Ruggles and Una Merkel. Based on the novel ‘Das Doppelte lottchen’ by Erich Kastner.

results.title: Heat
results.creator_credit: Michael Mann, Art Linson, Regency Entertainment (USA) and Monarchy Enterprises B. V.
results.brief_description: Neil McCauley (Robert De Niro) is a professional. He is meticulous and cautious. He also is a professional robber. After a successful heist, LA cop Vincent Hanna (Al Pacino) is on McCauley’s trail and out to stop him. The two are soon caught in an epic battle and yet they recognise that they are actually essentialy the same. Michael Mann’s “Heat” is a rivetting action film which also attempts to examine in some depth the lives of the film’s characters, in particular Vincent and Neil as well as the other members of his team. By casting dynamic actors like De Niro and Pacino in the lead roles, as well as Val Kilmer and John Voight in supporting roles, the focus on character remains engaging in the midst of the explosive violence of the action sequences which drive the film along.

results.title: The Texas chain saw massacre (D)
results.brief_description: Loosely based on the grizzly exploits of American serial killer Ed Gein (also a model for Norman Bates in “Psycho”), Tobe Hooper’s “The Texas chain saw massacre” rightly deserves its place as a horror classic. Five teenagers travelling through Texas (two of them brother and sister investigating the mysterious desecration of their grandfather’s grave), pick up a creepy hitchhiker and find themselves embroiled in a macabre and nightmarish reverse of southern hospitality. From its eerie opening images to its shocking finale, “The Texas chain saw massacre’ was initially considered a cheap drive-in exploitation film but, through strong critical appraisal, went on to be screened as part of the director’s fortnight at Cannes and the American Museum of Modern Art now has a print of it in its permanent collection. Cast includes Marilyn Burns, Allen Danziger and Gunnar Hansen as Leatherface.

results.title: The English patient (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Anthony Minghella, Saul Zaentz and Miramax Films
results.brief_description: Based on Michael Ondaatje’s Booker prize-winning novel, “The English Patient” is a sumptuous romance set during the second world war in the deserts of North Africa and the rolling hills of Tuscany. Hana (Juliette Binoche), a shell-shocked Canadian nurse decides to stay in an abandoned villa to nurse a mysterious English patient (Ralph Fiennes) who is burned beyond recognition and doesn’t remember his name. Gradually we learn the truth of his identity and of his doomed love affair with Katherine Mansfield (Kristen Scott Thomas). Winner of 9 Oscars at the 1996 Academy Awards, including Best Film, Best Director, Best Supporting Actress (Juliette Binoche) and Best Cinematography for Australian John Seale.

results.title: Seven years in Tibet (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Jean-Jacques Annaud, Iain Smith, John H. Williams, Applecross Productions and Reperage and Vanguard Films
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Austrian climber Heinrich Harrer, this is the amazing true story of his friendship with the Dalai Lama. Climbing in the Himalayas, Harrer is captured as a POW in China at the start of the second world war. He manages to escape the camp and flees across the mountains into isolated Tibet. As one of the few foreigners to ever enter Tibet, Harrer forms a friendship with the young Dalai Lama and becomes his confidante. The film depicts the most tumultuous period of Tibetan history in which China invades and occupies Tibet - an oppression which continues to this day.

results.title: Up close & personal (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Jon Avnet, Jordan Kerner, David Nicksay and Touchstone Pictures
results.brief_description: From humble beginnings, Sally Atwater (Michelle Pfeiffer) is about to hit the big time. Arriving from a trailer park in Nevada, an overeager and overdressed weather girl, she makes a disastrous debut on national television. All is not lost however as her passion for the job captures the eye of the experienced, and handsome newsman, Warren Justice (Robert Redford). With Warren’s help Sally is transformed, Pygmalian style, into a popular and respected journalist. Along the way romance develops, but this is threatened by Sally’s newfound success and they must find a balance between love and their successful careers. Cast includes Stockard Channing, Joe Mantegna and Kate Nelligan.
